title: GOLDTHREAD: Overview, Uses, Side Effects, Precautions, Interactions, Dosing and Reviews
description: Learn more about GOLDTHREAD uses, effectiveness, possible side effects, interactions, dosage, user ratings and products that contain GOLDTHREAD.
cleaned_text: Overview Goldthread is used for digestive disorders, a [skin infection](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/skin-infection-signs)caused by Leishmania [parasites](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/ss/slideshow-pictures-of-parasites), a sexually transmitted infection caused by [Trichomonas vaginalis](https://www.webmd.com/sexual-conditions/trichomoniasis), and other conditions, but there is no good scientific evidence to support these uses. How does it work ? [stomach](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/picture-of-the-stomach). It also appears to have antibacterial effects and may reduce swelling. Uses & Effectiveness Insufficient Evidence for - Digestive problems. - Skin infection caused by Leishmania parasites (Leishmania lesions). - A sexually transmitted infection Trichomonas vaginalis (trichomoniasis). - Scaly, [itchy skin](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/skin-conditions-pruritus)( [psoriasis](https://www.webmd.com/skin-problems-and-treatments/psoriasis/understanding-psoriasis-basics)). - Other conditions. Side Effects [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/ss/slideshow-mouth-problems): There is not enough information to know if goldthread is safe in medicinal amounts. Special Precautions and Warnings [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/ss/slideshow-mouth-problems): There is not enough information to know if goldthread is safe in medicinal amounts. Children: Goldthread is LIKELY UNSAFE in children, especially infants. It contains a chemical called berberine that can increase the amount of bilirubin in newborns. Bilirubin is a chemical released by the [liver](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/picture-of-the-liver). Too much bilirubin can lead to permanent [brain damage](https://www.webmd.com/brain/brain-damage-symptoms-causes-treatments)in newborns, especially in newborns born too early. Pregnancy: Goldthread is LIKELY UNSAFE during pregnancy. It contains a chemical called berberine that is thought to cross the [placenta](https://www.webmd.com/baby/should-i-eat-my-placenta)and may cause harm to the [developing child](https://www.webmd.com/parenting/baby/ss/slideshow-baby-milestones-first-year). [Brain damage](https://www.webmd.com/brain/ss/slideshow-concussions-brain-injuries)due to too much bilirubin has developed in [newborn](https://www.webmd.com/parenting/baby/rm-quiz-newborn-typical)infants exposed to berberine. Early research suggests pregnant women who take goldthread during the first three months of pregnancy increase the risk that their newborns will have birth defects affecting the [central nervous system](https://www.webmd.com/brain/what-is-nervous-system). [Breast](https://www.webmd.com/women/picture-of-the-breasts)-feeding: Goldthread is LIKELY UNSAFE when taken by [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/rm-quiz-mouth-myths)by breast-feeding mothers. Berberine and other harmful chemicals in goldthread can be transferred to the [infant](https://www.webmd.com/parenting/baby/video/why-babies-cry)through breast milk. Interactions Cyclosporine (Neoral, Sandimmune) interacts with GOLDTHREAD The body breaks down cyclosporine (Neoral, Sandimmune) to get rid of it. Goldthread might decrease how fast the body breaks down cyclosporine (Neoral, Sandimmune). This might cause there to be too much cyclosporine (Neoral, Sandimmune) in the body and potentially cause side effects. Medications changed by the liver (Cytochrome P450 3A4 (CYP3A4) substrates) interacts with GOLDTHREAD Some medications are changed and broken down by the liver. Goldthread might decrease how quickly the liver breaks down some medications. Taking goldthread along with some medications that are broken down by the liver can increase the effects and side effects of some medications. Before taking goldthread, talk to your healthcare provider if you are taking any medications that are changed by the liver.
